1.a: God has spoken in the past through the prophets at many times and in many ways.
1.q: How has God spoken in the past?

1.a: God has spoken in these recent days through a Son.
1.q: How has God spoken in these recent days?

1.a: The universe was made through the Son of God.
1.q: Through whom was the universe made?

1.a: All things are sustained by the word of the Son of God's power.
The Son is the radiance of God's glory, and the character of God's essence.
1.q: How does the Son display the glory and essence of God?

1.a: The Son of God is superior to the angels.
1.q: How does the Son of God compare to the angels?

1.a: God commanded the angels to worship the Son when the Son was brought into the world.
1.q: What did God command the angels to do when the Son was brought into the world?

1.a: The Son will rule as a king for ever and ever.
1.q: How long will the Son rule as a king?

1.a: The Son loves righteousness and the Son hates lawlessness.
1.q: What does the Son love and what does the Son hate?

1.a: The earth and heavens will wear out like a garment and perish.
1.q: What will happen to the earth and heavens over time?

1.a: God told the Son to sit at his right hand until God made the Son's enemies a stool for the Son's feet.
1.q: Where did God tell the Son to sit, and until what happened?

1.a: The angels care for those who are about to inherit salvation.
1.q: For whom do the angels care?

2.a: Believers must pay attention to what they have heard so that they do not drift away from it.
2.q: Why must believers pay attention to what they have heard?

2.a: Every transgression and disobedience receives just punishment.
2.q: What does every transgression and disobedience receive?

2.a: God testified to the message by signs, wonders, powerful deeds, and by the gifts of the Holy Spirit.
2.q: How did God testify to the message of salvation announced by the Lord?

2.a: Angels will not rule the world to come.
2.q: Who will not rule the world to come?

2.a: Man will rule the world to come.
2.q: Who will rule the world to come?

2.a: Jesus was crowned with glory and honor because of his suffering and death.
2.q: Why was Jesus crowned with glory and honor?

2.a: Jesus tasted death for every man.
2.q: For whom did Jesus taste death?

2.a: God plans to bring many sons to glory.
2.q: Who does God plan to bring to glory?

2.a: Both the one who sanctifies and those who are sanctified come from the one source, God.
2.q: Who both come from the one source, God?

2.a: The devil was made ineffective through Jesus' death.
2.q: Who was made ineffective through Jesus' death?

2.a: Through the death of Jesus, people are freed from the fear of death.
2.q: From what slavery are people freed through the death of Jesus?

2.a: It was necessary so that he might become a merciful and faithful high priest over God's things, and so he might achieve forgiveness for the people's sins.
2.q: Why was it necessary for Jesus to be like his brothers in all ways?

2.a: Jesus is able to help those who are tempted because he was tempted also.
2.q: Why is Jesus able to help those who are tempted?

3.a: The author gives Jesus the titles Apostle and High Priest.
3.q: What two titles does the author of the book of Hebrews give Jesus?

3.a: Jesus has been considered worthy of greater glory because while Moses was faithful in all God's house, Jesus is the one who built the house.
3.q: Why has Jesus been considered worthy of greater glory than Moses?

3.a: Moses was a servant in God's house.
3.q: What was Moses' role in God's house?

3.a: Moses gave testimony about the things that were to be spoken of in the future.
3.q: About what did Moses give testimony?

3.a: Jesus is the Son in charge of God's house.
3.q: What is Jesus' role in God's house?

3.a: The believers are God's house if they hold fast their confidence.

3.q: What did the Israelites in the wilderness do when they heard God's voice?

3.a: God swore that they would not enter his rest.
3.q: What did God swear concerning the Israelites who went astray in their hearts?

3.a: The brothers are warned to be careful not to turn away from the living God by unbelief.
3.q: Of what are the brothers warned to be careful?

3.a: The brothers are to encourage one another daily.
3.q: What are the brothers to do in order to avoid being hardened by the deceitfulness of sin?

3.a: As partners of Christ, believers must firmly hold their confidence in him from the beginning to the end.
3.q: As partners of Christ, what must believers do?

3.a: God was angry with those who sinned in the wilderness.
3.q: With whom was God angry for forty years?

3.a: Their dead bodies lay in the wilderness.
3.q: What happened to those with whom God was angry?

3.a: They were not able to enter God's rest because of unbelief.
3.q: Why were the disobedient Israelites not able to enter God's rest?

4.a: The believers and the Israelites had both heard the good news about God's rest.
4.q: What good news had the believers and the Israelites both heard?

4.a: The good news did not benefit the Israelites because they did not join faith to it.
4.q: Why did the good news not benefit the Israelites?

4.a: Those who have believed enter God's rest.
4.q: Who are the ones who enter God's rest?

4.a: God finished his created works at the beginning of the world and then rested on the seventh day.
4.q: When did God finish his created works and then rest?

4.a: God said that the Israelites would not enter his rest.
4.q: What did God say about the Israelites and his rest?

4.a: God has set "Today" as the day for people to enter his rest.
4.q: What day has God now set for people to enter his rest?

4.a: A person must listen to God's voice and not harden his heart.
4.q: What must a person do in order to enter God's rest?

4.a: A sabbath rest is still reserved for God's people.
4.q: What is still reserved for God's people?

4.a: A person who enters God's rest also rests from his deeds.
4.q: A person who enters God's rest also rests from what?

4.a: Believers should be eager to enter God's rest so that they do not fall as the Israelites did.
4.q: Why should believers be eager to enter God's rest?

4.a: The word of God is sharper than any two-edged sword.
4.q: What is the word of God sharper than?

4.a: The word of God is able to divide soul from spirit, and joints from marrow.
4.q: What is the word of God able to divide?

4.a: The word of God is able to discern the thoughts and intentions of the heart.
4.q: What is the word of God able to discern?

4.a: No created thing is hidden from God's sight.
4.q: Who is hidden from God's sight?

4.a: Jesus the Son of God serves as the great high priest for believers.
4.q: Who serves as the great high priest for believers?

4.a: Jesus feels sympathy for the weaknesses of believers because he was in all ways tempted.
4.q: Why does Jesus feel sympathy for the weaknesses of believers?
How many times did Jesus sin?

4.a: In time of need, believers are to come up with confidence to the throne of grace.
4.q: In time of need, what are believers to do to receive mercy and find grace?

5.a: For the people, every high priest offers gifts and sacrifices for sins.
5.q: What does every high priest do on behalf of the people?

5.a: The high priest also presents sacrifices for his sins.
5.q: In addition to the people, for whom does the high priest also present sacrifices?

5.a: A man must be called by God to be a high priest of God.
5.q: How does a man receive the honor of being a high priest of God?

5.a: God declared Christ to be a high priest.
5.q: Who declared Christ to be a high priest?

5.a: Christ is God's high priest forever.
5.q: For how long is Christ God's high priest?

5.a: Christ is a high priest of the order of Melchizedek.
5.q: Of what order is Christ as a high priest?

5.a: Christ was heard by God because he revered God.
5.q: Why was Christ heard by God when he prayed?

5.a: Christ learned obedience from the things he suffered.
For everyone who obeys him, Christ became the cause of their eternal salvation.
5.q: For whom did Christ become the cause of eternal salvation?

5.a: The original readers were dull of hearing.
5.q: What was the spiritual condition of the original readers of this letter?

5.a: Believers grow spiritually by practicing distinguishing right from wrong, discerning both good and evil.
5.q: How does the author of the letter say that believers grow from spiritual babies into full-grown adults?

6.a: The author of Hebrews wants the believers to press on to maturity.
6.q: On to what does the author of Hebrews want the believers to press?

6.a: The foundational teachings are repentance from dead works, faith in God, baptisms, laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment.
6.q: What teachings does the author list as the foundation of the message of Christ?

6.a: It is impossible for those who were sharers in the Holy Spirit, but then fell away, to be restored again to repentance.
6.q: What is impossible for those who were sharers in the Holy Spirit, but then fell away, to do?

6.a: These enlightened people had tasted the heavenly gift, God's word, and the powers of the age to come.
6.q: What had these enlightened people tasted?

6.a: They are not able to be restored because they have crucified for themselves the very Son of God.
6.q: Why are these people not able to be restored to repentance?

6.a: Land that receives rain but bears thorns and thistles has its end in burning.
6.q: In the author's analogy, what happens to land that receives rain but bears thorns and thistles?

6.a: The author expects better things concerning these believers, things that are about salvation.
6.q: What is the author's expectation concerning the believers to whom he is writing?

6.a: God will not forget their work, love, and service to the saints.
6.q: What will God not forget about these believers?

6.a: The believers should imitate the faith and patience of those who inherit the promises of God.
6.q: What should the believers imitate about those who inherit the promises of God?

6.a: Abraham had to wait patiently to obtain what God promised him.
6.q: What did Abraham have to do in order to obtain what God promised him?

6.a: God guaranteed his promise with an oath to show more clearly the unchangeable quality of his purpose.
6.q: Why did God guarantee his promise with an oath?

6.a: It is impossible for God to lie.
6.q: What is it impossible for God to do?

6.a: The believer's confidence in God is a secure and reliable anchor for his soul.
6.q: What does the believer's confidence in God do for his soul?

6.a: Jesus entered into the inner place behind the curtain as the forerunner for the believers.
6.q: Where did Jesus enter as the forerunner for the believers?

7.a: Melchizedek was king of Salem and priest of God Most High.
7.q: What two titles did Melchizedek have?

7.a: Abraham gave Melchizedek a tenth of everything he had captured.
The name Melchizedek means "king of righteousness" and "king of peace".
7.q: What does the name Melchizedek mean?

7.a: Melchizedek was without ancestors and has no end of life.
7.q: Who were the ancestors of Melchizedek, and when did he die?

7.a: The priests of the Law are descended from Levi and Abraham.
7.q: From whom are the priests descended, who are priests according to the Law, and who collect tithes from the people?

7.a: Melchizedek was the greater person because he blessed Abraham
7.q: Who was the greater person, Abraham or Melchizedek?

7.a: Levi also paid tithes to Melchizedek because Levi was in the genitals of Abraham when Abraham paid tithes to Melchizedek.
7.q: In what way did Levi himself also pay tithes to Melchizedek?

7.a: There was a need for another priest to arise after the order of Melchizedek because perfection was not possible through the Levitical priesthood.
7.q: Why was there a need for another priest to arise after the order of Melchizedek?

7.a: The law must be changed when the priesthood changes.
7.q: What must also be 3changed when the priesthood changes?

7.a: Jesus descended from the tribe of Judah, which had never served before at the altar as priests.
7.q: From which tribe did Jesus descend, and had this tribe served before at the altar as priests?

7.a: Jesus became a priest after the order of Melchizedek based on the power of an indestructible life.
7.q: On what basis did Jesus become a priest after the order of Melchizedek?

7.a: The former commandment, the Law, has been set aside because it is weak and useless.
7.q: What has been set aside because it is weak and useless?

7.a: God swore that Jesus would be a priest forever.
7.q: What oath did God swear concerning Jesus?

7.a: Jesus is the guarantee of a better covenant.
7.q: Of what is Jesus the guarantee?

7.a: Jesus is able to completely save those who draw near to God through him because he always lives to intercede for them.
7.q: Why is Jesus able to completely save those who draw near to God through him?

7.a: Jesus is sinless, blameless, pure, and separated from sinners.
7.q: What four attributes does Jesus have that make him the right priest for believers?

7.a: Jesus offered up himself once for the sins of the people.
7.q: What offering did Jesus make for the sins of the people?

7.a: Jesus did not need to make any offering for his own sins because he is sinless.
7.q: What offering did Jesus need to make for his own sins?

7.a: The priests who were appointed through the Law were weak, but Jesus has been made perfect forever.
7.q: How is Jesus different from the priests who were appointed through the Law?

8.a: The believers' high priest is sitting at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens.
8.q: Where is the believers' high priest sitting?

8.a: The true tabernacle is in the heavens.
Every priest must have something to offer.
8.q: What is necessary for every priest to have?

8.a: The priests who offered gifts according to the Law were on the earth.
8.q: Where were the priests who offered gifts according to the Law?

8.a: The priests on earth served a copy and shadow of the heavenly things.
8.q: What did the priests on earth serve?

8.a: The earthly tabernacle was built according to the pattern God showed Moses on the mountain.
8.q: According to what pattern was the earthly tabernacle built?

8.a: Christ has a superior priestly ministry because he is the mediator of a better covenant, established on better promises.
8.q: Why does Christ have a superior priestly ministry?

8.a: God promised to make a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah.
8.q: What did God promise when he found fault with the people under the first covenant?

8.a: God said he would put his laws into the people's minds, and write them on their hearts.
8.q: What did God say he would do in the new covenant?

8.a: In the new covenant, all would know the Lord, from the least to the greatest.
8.q: In the new covenant, who would know the Lord?

8.a: God said he would remember the people's sins no more.
8.q: What did God say he would do with the people's sins in the new covenant?

8.a: In announcing a new covenant, God made the first covenant old and ready to disappear.
8.q: In announcing a new covenant, what did God make the first covenant?

9.a: The place of worship for the first covenant was the tabernacle on earth.
9.q: What was the place of worship for the first covenant?

9.a: In the holy place of the earthly tabernacle were the lampstand, the table, and the bread of the presence.
9.q: What was located in the holy place of the earthly tabernacle?

9.a: In the most holy place of the earthly tabernacle were the altar for incense and the ark of the covenant.
9.q: What was located in the most holy place of the earthly tabernacle?

9.a: The high priest entered the most holy place once each year, after making a blood sacrifice for himself and the people.
9.q: How often did the high priest enter the most holy place, and what did he do before he entered?

9.a: The earthly tabernacle and the gifts and sacrifices being offered there served as an illustration in the present time.
9.q: What served as an illustration in the present time for the readers of this letter?

9.a: The offerings of the earthly tabernacle were not able to perfect the worshiper's conscience.
9.q: What were the offerings of the earthly tabernacle not able to do?

9.a: The regulations of the earthly tabernacle were provided until the new order would be put in place.
9.q: Until when were the regulations of the earthly tabernacle provided?

9.a: The sacred tent in which Christ serves is more perfect, is not made by human hands, and does not belong to this created world.
9.q: What is different about the sacred tent in which Christ serves?

9.a: Christ made an offering of his own blood by which he entered the most holy place.
9.q: What offering did Christ make, by which he entered the most holy place?

9.a: Christ's offering secured everlasting redemption for everyone.
Christ's blood cleanses the believer's conscience from dead deeds in order to serve the living God.
9.q: What does Christ's blood do for the believer?

9.a: Christ is the mediator of a new covenant.
9.q: Of what is Christ the mediator?

9.a: A death is required in order for a will to be in force.
9.q: What is required in order for a will to be in force?

9.a: The death of calves and goats was required for the first covenant.
9.q: What death was required for the first covenant?

9.a: Without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness of sins.
9.q: What cannot happen without the shedding of blood?

9.a: Christ now appears in heaven itself, in the presence of God, on our behalf.
9.q: Where does Christ now appear on our behalf?

9.a: Christ offers himself one time at the end of the ages to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself.
9.q: How many times must Christ offer himself to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself?

9.a: After every person dies, they face the judgment.
9.q: For every person, what happens after their death?

9.a: Christ will appear a second time for the salvation of those who wait patiently for him.
9.q: For what purpose will Christ appear a second time?

10.a: The Law is only a shadow of the realities in Christ.
10.q: What is the Law compared to the realities in Christ?

10.a: The repeated sacrifices made through the Law remind the worshipers of sins committed year after year.
10.q: Of what do the repeated sacrifices made through the Law remind the worshipers?

10.a: It is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins.
10.q: What is it impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to do?

10.a: God prepared a body for Christ.
10.q: What did God prepare for Christ when Christ came into the world?

10.a: God set aside the first practice of the sacrifices offered according to the Law.
10.q: What practice did God set aside when Christ came into the world?

10.a: God established the second practice of the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.
10.q: What practice did God establish when Christ came into the world?

10.a: Christ is waiting until his enemies are humbled and made a stool for his feet.
10.q: For what is Christ waiting as he sits at the right side of God?

10.a: Christ has perfected forever those who are sanctified by his one offering.
10.q: What has Christ done for those sanctified by his one offering?

10.a: Additional offerings are no longer required where there is forgiveness of sins.
10.q: What is no longer required where there is forgiveness of sins?

10.a: Believers can now enter the most holy place by Jesus' blood.
10.q: Into what place can believers now enter by Jesus' blood?

10.a: The believer's heart has been sprinkled clean from an evil conscience, and his body has been washed with pure water.
10.q: What has been sprinkled and what has been washed in the believer?

10.a: Believers must hold tightly to the confession of their confident expectation.
10.q: To what must believers hold tightly?

10.a: Believers must encourage one another more and more as they see the day drawing near.
10.q: What must believers do as they see the day drawing near?

10.a: The expectation of those who deliberately go on sinning after receiving the knowledge of the truth is judgment and a fire that consumes God's enemies.
10.q: What is the expectation of those who deliberately go on sinning after receiving the knowledge of the truth?

10.a: The person who treats the blood of Christ by which he was sanctified as something unholy deserves punishment without mercy beyond the punishment given under the Law of Moses.
10.q: What does the person deserve who treats the blood of Christ by which he was sanctified as something unholy?

10.a: Vengeance belongs to the Lord.
10.q: To whom does vengeance belong?

10.a: The believers had accepted with joy the seizure of their possessions, knowing they had a better and everlasting possession.
10.q: How had the believers who received this letter reacted to the seizure of their possessions?

10.a: The believer needs confidence and patience so he may receive what God has promised.
10.q: What does the believer need so he may receive what God has promised?

10.a: The righteous will live by faith.
10.q: How will the righteous live?

10.a: God is not pleased with those who turn back.
10.q: What does God think of those who turn back?

10.a: The author's expectation is that those who received this letter will have faith for keeping their souls.
10.q: What is the author's expectation for those who received this letter?

11.a: A person of faith confidently expects and has certainty toward God's promises that are yet to be fulfilled.
11.q: What attitude does a person of faith have toward God's promises that are yet to be fulfilled?

11.a: The visible things of the universe were not made out of things that were visible.
11.q: From what were the visible things of the universe created?

11.a: God praised Abel because Abel by faith offered God a more appropriate sacrifice than Cain did.
11.q: Why did God praise Abel for being righteous?

11.a: One who comes to God must believe that God exists and that he rewards those who seek him.
11.q: What must one who comes to God believe about God?

11.a: Noah demonstrated his faith by building a ship to save his family according to God's warning.
11.q: How did Noah demonstrate his faith?

11.a: Abraham and Sarah received by faith the power to conceive even when they were too old.
11.q: What promise did Abraham and Sarah receive by faith?

11.a: The ancestors of faith saw and welcomed God's promises from far off.
11.q: What did the ancestors of faith see from far off?

11.a: The ancestors of faith considered themselves strangers and aliens on the earth.
11.q: What did the ancestors of faith consider themselves on the earth?

11.a: God has prepared a heavenly city for those of faith.
11.q: What has God prepared for those of faith?

11.a: Abraham believed God would be able to raise up Isaac from the dead.
11.q: What did Abraham believe God would be able to do even as he offered up Isaac his only son?

11.a: Joseph prophesied of the departure of the children of Israel from Egypt when his end was near.
11.q: What did Joseph prophesy by faith when his end was near?

11.a: Moses chose by faith to share mistreatment with God's people, considering the disgrace of following Christ as greater riches.
11.q: What did Moses choose to do by faith when he had grown up?

11.a: Moses observed the Passover and the sprinkling of the blood by faith in order to save the Israelites' firstborn sons.
11.q: What did Moses observe by faith in order to save the Israelites' firstborn sons?

11.a: Rahab by faith received the spies in safety which prevented her from perishing.
11.q: What did Rahab do by faith which prevented her from perishing?

11.a: Some of the ancestors of faith conquered kingdoms, escaped the sword, became mighty in war, and caused foreign armies to flee.
11.q: What did some of the ancestors of faith accomplish in war?

11.a: Some of the ancestors of faith suffered torture, mocking, whippings, chains, imprisonments, stoning, sawing in two, death, and destitution.
11.q: What did some of the ancestors of faith suffer?

11.a: Despite the faith of these ancestors, they did not receive in their earthly lives what God had promised them.
11.q: Despite the faith of these ancestors, what did they not receive in their earthly lives?

11.a: The ancestors of faith will receive the promises of God and be perfected with the new covenant believers in Christ.
11.q: With whom will the ancestors of faith receive the promises of God and be perfected?

12.a: Since he is surrounded by such a large crowd of witnesses, the believer should throw off the sin that easily entangles him.
12.q: Why should the believer throw off the sin that easily entangles him?

12.a: Jesus endured the cross and despised its shame for the joy that was set before him.
12.q: Why did Jesus endure the cross and despise its shame?

12.a: By considering Jesus who endured hateful speech from sinners, a believer can avoid becoming weary or fainthearted.
12.q: How can a believer avoid becoming weary or fainthearted?

12.a: The Lord disciplines those whom he loves and receives.
12.q: What does the Lord do to those whom he loves and receives?

12.a: A person without the Lord's discipline is an illegitimate child and not God's child.
12.q: What is a person who is without the Lord's discipline?

12.a: God disciplines his children for their good so they can share in his holiness
12.q: Why does God discipline his children?

12.a: Discipline produces peaceful fruit of righteousness.
Believers should pursue peace with all people.
12.q: What should believers pursue with all people?

12.a: A root of bitterness must not grow up and cause trouble and pollute many.
12.q: What must not grow up and cause trouble and pollute many?

12.a: Esau was rejected when he desired to inherit the blessing with tears after selling his own birthright.
12.q: What happened to Esau when he desired to inherit the blessing with tears after selling his own birthright?

12.a: The Israelites begged that not another word be spoken to them.
12.q: For what did the Israelites beg at the mountain where God spoke?

12.a: Believers in Christ come to Mount Zion and to the city of the living God.
12.q: To where do believers in Christ come instead of the mountain where the Israelites heard the voice of God?

12.a: Believers in Christ come to the assembly of all the firstborn registered in heaven.
12.q: To what assembly do believers in Christ come?

12.a: Believer in Christ come to God the Judge of all, to the spirits of the righteous, and to Jesus.
12.q: To whom do believers in Christ come?

12.a: Those who turn away will not escape from God.
12.q: What will happen to those who turn away from the one who warns them from heaven?

12.a: God has promised to shake the earth and the heavens.
12.q: What has God promised to shake?

12.a: The believers will receive a kingdom that cannot be shaken.
12.q: What will the believers receive instead of the things that can be shaken?

12.a: Believers should worship God with reverence and awe.
Believers should worship God in this way because he is a consuming fire.
12.q: Why should believers worship God in this way?

13.a: Some have welcomed angels without knowing it.
13.q: What have some done by welcoming strangers?

13.a: Believers should remember them as if they were in prison also, and as if their bodies were being mistreated also.
13.q: How should believers remember those in prison?

13.a: Marriage must be respected by all.
13.q: What must be respected by all?

13.a: God judges the sexually immoral and adulterers.
13.q: What does God do with the sexually immoral and adulterers?

13.a: A believer can be free from the love of money because God has said he will never leave nor forsake him.
13.q: How can a believer be free from the love of money?

13.a: Believers should imitate the faith of those who have led them and who have spoken God's word to them.
The author warns the believers about strange teachings involving rules about food.
13.q: About what kind of strange teachings does the author warn the believers?

13.a: The bodies of the animals were burned outside the camp.
13.q: Where were the bodies of the animals used for sacrifice in the holy place burned?

13.a: Jesus suffered outside the city gate.
Believers must go to Jesus outside the camp, bearing his disgrace.
13.q: Where must believers go, and why?

13.a: Believers have no permanent city here on earth.
13.q: What permanent city do believers have here on earth?

13.a: Believers seek the city that is to come instead.
13.q: What city do believers seek instead?

13.a: Believers should constantly offer up sacrifices of praise to God.
13.q: What sacrifice should believers constantly offer up to God?

13.a: Believers should obey and submit to their leaders.
13.q: What attitude should believers have toward their leaders?

13.a: God works in the believer that which is well pleasing in God's sight.
13.q: What does God work in the believer?

13.a: The author will come with Timothy when he visits the believers.
13.q: With whom will the author come when he visits the believers?
